keyTakeAways: Reefline is a 7-mile-long artificial reef near Miami Beach designed to restore lost coral habitat and serve as an underwater ecotourism destination.
The project combines marine science and art, using concrete sculptures—such as cars and starfish—as coral substrates for growth.
Colin Foord, a coral scientist and founder of Coral Morphologic, is responsible for growing and transplanting resilient corals to the reef.
Ximena Caminos, an arts curator from Argentina, is the artistic director and cultural placemaker behind the project, aiming to revitalize Miami Beach through art and ecological restoration.
The project is funded by a $5 million city bond and aims to raise $6 million more for its first phase, with public access to the reef in shallow water (15–20 feet deep).
The coral nursery at Foord's warehouse houses over 2,000 soft coral specimens, with some species expected to grow up to 6 feet tall.
Leandro Ehrlich, an internationally recognized artist, contributes sculptures that will eventually be colonized by coral, transforming into living ecosystems.
Reefline aims to restore a historic coral reef that once existed in Miami Beach but was lost due to sand replenishment in the 1970s.
The project includes an onshore marine learning center to educate the public about endangered coral reefs.
Future phases may include a constellation of 57 giant starfish sculptures, potentially becoming a symbolic icon for Miami.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Miami Beach is launching a groundbreaking 7-mile-long artificial reef project called Reefline, which blends marine science and art to restore a historic coral reef lost in the 1970s. Led by coral scientist Colin Foord and arts curator Ximena Caminos, the project features underwater concrete sculptures—such as cars and starfish—designed to support coral growth. Foord’s coral nursery grows over 2,000 soft coral specimens, including gorgonians, which will be transplanted into shallow waters off Miami Beach. The project is funded by a $5 million city bond and aims to raise $6 million more, with public access from the shore. Over time, the sculptures will be colonized by coral, transforming into vibrant underwater ecosystems. The initiative not only restores ecological balance but also creates a unique ecotourism destination and a lasting cultural symbol for the city.
title: Miami Beach puts the art in offshore artificial reef
